section.title: What is &sudo;?
section.para:
&sudo; is an abbreviation for super user do. It is a Linux command that you can use to execute programs as a &rootuser; user. &sudo; gives you elevated privileges when you want to run important commands. The &rootuser; user is the Linux superuser and the equivalent to the administrator who has maximum permissions to do anything to the system.
As a normal user on Linux, you have reduced permissions. For example, you cannot write to system directories. For security reasons, the normal user is separate from the &rootuser; user. You must have &rootuser; privileges to run commands which can only be executed by the &rootuser;. The following options to log in as &rootuser; are available:

listitem.para: su: allows you to run a command as &rootuser; but requires you to know the &rootuser; password.

note.title: &rootuser; vs. &sudo;
note.para: For security reasons and to avoid mistakes, it is not recommended to log in as &rootuser;. With &sudo; you can log in as a normal user and execute commands with elevated privileges.

section.para: The &sudo; package is installed by on all &productname; distributions by default.
